Agromyzes flavus is a species of Gram-positive, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacteria that belongs to the genus Agromyces. It was first isolated from soil samples collected in Japan.

The cells of Agromyzes flavus are typically rod-shaped, with a size range of 0.3-0.5 μm in width and 1.0-2.5 μm in length. The colonies formed by this species on agar plates are usually yellow in color, due to the production of carotenoid pigments.

Agromyzes flavus is characterized by its ability to grow at temperatures ranging from 10°C to 37°C, with an optimal growth temperature around 28°C. It can utilize a variety of carbohydrates as carbon sources, including glucose, fructose, and sucrose.

Phylogenetically, Agromyzes flavus is closely related to other Agromyces species and is classified within the family Microbacteriaceae, which is part of the phylum Actinobacteria.

The ecological role of Agromyzes flavus in natural environments is not yet fully understood, but it is believed to be involved in the decomposition of organic matter in soil and may play a role in nutrient cycling.
